{{ja-kanjitab|まん|よう|か|k3=が|な|r=y}}<!-- This is on'yomi for the ''man'yō'' part, but kun'yomi for the ''kana'' part. -->

===Etymology===
Compound of {{compound|lang=ja|sort=まんようがな|万葉|tr1=man'yō|t1=ten thousand leaves|pos1=from the title of the {{etyl|ojp|-}} poetry anthology, [[w:Man'yōshū|''Man'yōshū'']], “Collection of Ten Thousand Leaves”|仮名|tr2=kana|t2=phonetic character|pos2=literally “borrowed characters” or “borrowed names”, from the way the characters were borrowed for their phonetic values}}.<ref name="KDJ">{{R:Kokugo Dai Jiten}}</ref><ref name="DJR">{{R:Daijirin}}</ref>

This kind of phonetic re-use of Chinese characters was broadly popularized by the the [[w:Man'yōshū|''Man'yōshū'']]. Chinese used phonetically to spell Japanese occurs even earlier in the historical record, such as on the [[w:Inariyama Sword|Inariyama Sword]], dated to 471 or 531.
